IRS990.MissionDescription: To preserve, educate, and promote understanding of Maine maritime history among the general public.
IRS990.Description: Collections and Exhibits: Includes all items relating to maritime history primarily in Maine. Paintings and other artwork, rigged models, half hulls, tools used in maritime history, navigating equipment, ship parts and watercraft on display. Exhibits include historic buildings and period displays of maritime life during the late 1800's. Includes the preservation of both new and existing displays.

Activity2.Description: Library and Archives: The library and archives house thousands of books, maritime manuscripts, business records, photographs, maps, charts, and ship plans. Includes purchasing, maintaining and storing, and restoring these items. The library is available for general and scholarly use.

Activity3.Description: Education & Public Programs: Lecture series, symposiums, adult and youth classes, school programs, senior college programs, boat lecture cruises, summer shipyard activities, Sherman Zwicker tours, volunteer support programs, family programs, museum trips, summer camps, trolly tours of Bath Iron Works, and other guided tours are all part of the education and public programs.

ActivityOther.Description: Boat shop: Buildings and building maintenance, mooring maintenance, workboat expenses, piers and their maintenance all necessary for the museum visitors.

NameBusiness.BusinessNameLine1: Culebra LLC dba Long Beach Cruises

Form990ScheduleDPartXIV.Explanation: Collection items purchased and donated are not included in the balance sheet. The costs of collection items are recorded as decreases in net assets in the statement of activities when purchased. The proceeds from the sale of collection items are recorded as increases in net assets in the statement of activities when sold. The Museum's extensive collection includes artifacts relating to the maritime history of Maine and its associated shoreline infrastructure. The collection includes many early 19th Century paintings and other artwork, rigged models and half models, tools used in maritime industries, important collections of navigating equipment, scrimshaw, furniture, textiles, fishing gear, ships' parts, and a strong historic watercraft collection. The Museum also preserves and interprets several historic buildings and structures, including five buildings from the Percy & Small Shipyard (1897-1920), and the historic Donnell House, which once belonged to a shipyard owner. The Library and Archives house thousands of books, maritime manuscripts, business records, photographs, maps and charts, ships' construction plans, and video and film archives. The Museum adopted a new Code of Ethics statement during 2007 (and amended during 2009) that is in accordance with the American Association of Museums guidelines and other museum industry best practices. It also has a collection policy. These policies delineate responsibilities in such matters as Museum ethics, acquisitions, loans, care of collections, and deaccessioning. Objects held in the collection are carefully tracked and monitored. Proceeds from the sale of an object deaccessioned may only be applied toward further collection acquisitions.

The Museum's extensive collection includes artifacts relating to the maritime history of Maine and its associated shoreline infrastructure. The collection includes many early 19th Century paintings and other artwork, rigged models and half models, tools used in maritime industries, important collections of navigating equipment, scrimshaw, furniture, textiles, fishing gear, and ships' parts, and a strong historic watercraft collection. The Museum also preserves and interprets several historic buildings and structures, including five buildings from the Percy & Small Shipyard (1897-1920), and the historic Donnell House, which once belonged to a shipyard owner. The Library and Archives house thousands of books, maritime manuscripts, business records, photographs, maps and charts, ships' construction plans, and video and film archives. These exhibits aid in promoting an understanding of Maine maritime History among the general public.

Form990ScheduleDPartXIV.Identifier: Description of Intended Use of Endowment Funds:
Form990ScheduleDPartXIV.Explanation: The intended uses of the Organization's endowment funds are for collection preservation, building maintenance, and educational purposes.

Form990ScheduleMPartII.Explanation: The Organization sells contributions of securities through its investment broker. All gifts of securities are sold as soon as administratively possible.

Collection items purchased and donated are not included in the balance sheet. The costs of collection items are recorded as decreases in net assets in the statement of activities when purchased. The proceeds from the sale of collection items are recorded as increases in net assets in the statement of activities when sold.

GeneralExplanation.Identifier: Form 990, Part VI, Section B, line 11
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: A copy of Form 990 is forwarded to the finance committee for their review. They formally review the 990 at their meeting. The executive committee then meets, votes to accept, and then the appropriate persons sign and submit the return.

GeneralExplanation.ReturnReference: Form 990, Part VI, Section B, line 12c
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: At the June meeting of incoming and departing trustees, the chairman of the board states the policy and the executive director confirms. Additionally, at the start of each board member meeting there is an opportunity for any individual to come forward to publicly or privately announce a potential conflict of interest.

GeneralExplanation.ReturnReference: Form 990, Part VI, Section B, line 15
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: In 2006, extensive effort was put in place by the board to determine adequate compensation at the time of the executive director's hiring. There is no annual review of the executive director's compensation. However, the Museum does partake in several comparability surveys to gather information for the board to evaluate the executive director's salary. Each year their salary is adjusted for increases in cost of living at the same rate as regular staff. The board of directors determines the amount of the cost of living increase. That figure is then voted on and approved by the board for all staff, including the executive director.

GeneralExplanation.ReturnReference: Form 990, Part VI, Section C, line 19
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: The Organization makes its governing documents, conflict of interest policy, and financial statements available to the public upon request.

GeneralExplanation.Identifier: Changes in Net Assets or Fund Balances:

GeneralExplanation.Explanation: The audit process has not changed from the prior year.
